Cool Things People Do With Their Blogs

https://brainbaking.com/post/2022/04/cool-things-people-do-with-their-blogs/

I‚Äôll try to periodically update it as I encounter more cool stuff. Enjoy!

Content related

  • Sync your laptop battery, local weather, and current location with your site: Aaron Parecki‚Äôs homepage
  • Publicly display global website statistics: Luke Harris' stats page
  • More stats: game playtime, AWStats server data: Roy Tang‚Äôs stats
  • Create and regularly update a ‚Äúuses‚Äù page: Ru Singh' uses page
  • Create and regularly update a ‚Äúnow‚Äù page: Derek Sivers' the /now page movement
  • Auto-import game metadata from How Long To Beat and others: Jefklak‚Äôs Codex games page
  • Use your own site to publish checkins instead of Foursquare: Henrique Dias' checkins
  • Regularly publish week reviews or link bundles: Stefan Imhoff‚Äôs Link Bundle #15
  • Have an ‚Äúon this day‚Äù page that displays posts from previous years: Frank Meeuwsen‚Äôs on this day archive
  • Group multiple posts into series: Amos' long-form series
  • Group multiple posts into research questions: Emmanuel Quartey‚Äôs questions section
  • Syndicate the HTTP blog to a Gemini capsule: Brain Baking Gemini (defunct)

Design related

  • Create an official coat of arms as the logo of your site: Marijn Florence‚Äôs heraldry adventure
  • Design your site around ever-evolving note-taking systems: Andy Matuschak‚Äôs Evergreen Notes
  • An audible frequency graph that determines posting activity: Chris Burnells' All posts archive
  • Write a custom dynamic blog engine from scratch, because we can: Jan-Lukas Else‚Äôs blog
  • Implement a simple client-site search using lunr.js: Brain Baking archives
  • Show articles from others blogs you read below your own articles: an article from Drew DeVault
  • Use a public inbox as a commenting system: an article from Drew DeVault
  • Implement reaction buttons for each post: Jan-Lukas Else‚Äôs thoughts on reactions
  • Emulate the multi-pane layout of an e-mail client: Brian Lovin‚Äôs writings
  • Each post has a unique HTML design/layout: Aegir‚Äôs Words

IndieWeb related

  • Have a guestbook page where people can send Webmentions to to sign it: Ana Rodrigues' guestbook
  • Collaborative pixel-art that gets saved every five minutes: Aaron Parecki‚Äôs IndieWebCamp Pixel Art
  • Publish replies to others' sites using Webmentions: James' Coffee Blog, Replies
  • Post Tweets on your own site first, then syndicate to Twitter: Sebastiaan Andeweg‚Äôs tweets
  • Summarize all IndieWeb-based RSVP events in a calendar: Jamie Tanna‚Äôs RSVPs
  • Work together on MicroPub/Sub as a new social reading protocol: Neal Mather‚Äôs blog
  • Join the IndieWeb ring to promote own and others' sites: Horst Gutmann‚Äôs blog
  • Build a custom Webmention receiver/sender: IndieWeb examples

RSS related

  • Provide multiple RSS feeds for notes, articles, etc: Ton Zijlstra‚Äôs feeds
  • Add query capabilities to RSS feeds: Eli‚Äôs RSS navigational tips
  • Automatic publishing of favorites from an RSS reader: Peter Rukavina‚Äôs favorites
  • Styled OPML Blogrolls that can be imported into your reader: Ruben Schade‚Äôs Omake OPML
  • Styled RSS feeds to better explain what a web feed is: Matt Webb‚Äôs RSS feed
  • A ‚ÄúReply via email‚Äù link in each RSS post to encourage interaction: Mike Harley‚Äôs RSS feed
  • Secret RSS-only posts that do not appear on the website: Ton Zƒ≥lstra‚Äôs RSS feed
  • Send out newsletters based on your RSS feed: Kev Quirk is newslettering again (defunct)
  • Add the location from where you write to your RSS feed: Ruben Schade‚Äôs RSS feed
